qas.question: What Neapolitan architect created the "Flying Chair" elevator?
At what location was the "Flying Chair" installed in 1845?
What type of wood was used on the inside ?

answers.text: a motor mechanic utilizing a system of toothed wheels

qas.question: What did the safety system consist of?

answers.text: a beam pushed outwards by a steel spring

context: In 1845, the Neapolitan architect <a0_0>Gaetano Genovese<a0_0/> installed in the <a1_0>Royal Palace of Caserta<a1_0/> the "Flying Chair", an elevator ahead of its time, covered with chestnut wood outside and with <a2_0>maple<a2_0/> wood inside. It included a light, two benches and a hand operated signal, and could be activated from the outside, without any effort on the part of the occupants. Traction was controlled by <a3_0>a motor mechanic utilizing a system of toothed wheels<a3_0/>. A safety system was designed to take effect if the cords broke. It consisted of <a4_0>a beam pushed outwards by a steel spring<a4_0/>.
